Award.AwardTitle: Diffraction-grating coupled surface emitting Terahertz quantum cascade laser source for high power, room temperature continuous wave operation

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract Title
Chip-based, High-Power Surface Emitting Terahertz Source

Abstract
Non-technical:
The terahertz (THz) radiation in the frequency range of ~1-5 THz has mainly unique properties and applications in imaging, sensing, spectroscopy, communication, and medical diagnosis. Most of these applications requires a sufficient THz light power density so that the light can pass through materials and able to be detected for analysis. This has fueled intense studies on the generation of high power THz light in the past decades. The recent demonstrated THz source based on nonlinear generation inside a mid-IR quantum cascade laser (QCL) is proved to be the only room temperature semiconductor light source that delivers mW-level power at room temperature in the 1-5 THz range. The main challenge for this type of sources is to generate higher THz power up to tens of milliwatts with good beam quality which is required by most of the real-world application. A novel approach is proposed to develop a chip-based THz source with high power output by extracting THz light from the entire cavity. This simple to use and compact source will be an enabling technology which will allow easy access to THz spectroscopy/ imaging for the broader scientific community.

Technical:
The objective of the proposed research is to demonstrate a room temperature, monolithic THz source with sub-milliwatt level output power in continuous wave operation and tens of milliwatt level in pulsed mode operation. In the previous demonstrations, edge-emitting THz sources based on nonlinear generation inside a mid-IR QCL have limited outcoupling efficiency (~6-10%) due to the limited outcoupling aperture size regarding to the entire cavity. The approach in this proposed project is to use a surface-emission scheme based on THz diffraction grating defined in the semi-insulating InP substrate of a epi-down bonded THz QCL source for high-power and efficient THz outcoupling. Unlike the traditional distributed-feedback (DFB) grating which interacts with the guiding laser modes by providing the optical feedback, the proposed THz diffraction grating simply diffract the incident Cerenkov emission cone into the discrete directions. With an optimized grating structure, surface emission from the entire cavity with diffraction efficiency up to 90% is achievable. This will drastically increase the THz outcoupling efficiency and power. In contrast to a THz sources based gas lasers, which is bulky and expensive, the proposed THz QCL source offers a monolithic solution that, once developed, has potential for cost-effective mass production using the existing semiconductor laser fabrication infrastructure. This project is an excellent example of a multidisciplinary approach used to circumvent existing technological limitations. Solid state physics, material science, nonlinear optics, and laser physics are all major components of the research plan, which are all supported generally by NSF, and are used, in this case, together to combine multiple functional elements into a single, compact, high power device.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF project ?Diffraction-grating coupled surface emitting Terahertz quantum cascade laser source for high power, room temperature continuous wave operation? (Federal Award ID: 1607838) addresses critical needs in the field of high-power continuous wave (CW), broadband THz laser source at room temperature. This type of chip-based comb source has numerous applications in basic sciences, as well as in spectroscopy, metrology, ranging and detection, astronomy, and environmental monitoring. With the support of this project, we create a revolutionary continuous wave monolithic THz laser source working at room temperature which is mass-producible, and has mW power output at room temperature continuous wave operation with a broad frequency tuning over 2.3 THz range.

The core achievements of this project are: (1) Demonstrated world's the most powerful semiconductor THz laser sources (14 μW at 293 K) based on quantum cascade lasers (QCLs) at 3.6 THz. (This work was published on Nature Scientific Reports: 6, 23595 (2016)). (2) Demonstrated the high-power diffraction grating coupled surface emitting THz QCL with improved outcoupling efficiency. (Photonics 3, 42, (2016)) Room temperature THz emitter is active area of investigation in the optoelectronic and physics communities. (3) Demonstrated the first THz frequency comb at 3.0 THz based on difference-frequency generation from a mid-IR QCL comb at room temperature continuous operation. (This work was recently published on Nature communications 10, 2403 (2019)). The accomplished results of this project aroused lots of interest to many people in these fields and received extensive scientific media reports, such as Northwestern McCormick News, etc. In addition, the demonstrated comb source will be of interest to a much wider community of scientists, for a variety of spectroscopic, imaging, and medical applications.

Broader impacts: With this research, we systematically address many basic problems existing for previous THz sources based on nonlinear generation from mid-IR QCL by using a diffraction grating to improve the THz outcoupling efficiency and the THz output. The demonstrated THz device has a chip size after packaging on submounts, operates at room temperature continuous wave operation with a broad spectrum tuning range of 2.3 THz. As such, it can be a drop-in replacement for existing light sources in many spectroscopy applications. Also, with significant potential for mass production, the source can be made cheaply, similar to the infrared diode lasers. With improved outcoupling efficiency, a new type of room temperature frequency comb based on nonlinear QCL generation is successfully achieved. The demonstrated THz frequency comb exhibits one order of magnitude of lower frequency noise and tuning compared with their mid-IR comb counterparts. This will allow many more people access to optical frequency comb sources for novel and unique research.

This NSF project also makes an excellent case study for how theory, technology, and experiment all play a role in developing a high-power THz frequency comb laser source. As such, aspects of the device design and fabrication have been incorporated into the Solid State Engineering curriculum at Northwestern University as real-world examples. Graduate students and post-docs funded through this work were able to present this work to course attendees and at conferences. The involvement of undergraduates and high-school students (through mentorship) has been emphasized, by leveraging existing programs with a strong focus on under-represented minorities, to increase the effectiveness and scope of the program.
